newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: Singapore investors top Wall Street buyers - paper.
newsitem.headline: Singapore investors top Wall Street buyers - paper.

text.p: Singapore-based investors poured US$3 billion into U.S. equities between January and June this year, making them the biggest foreign buyers of Wall Street stocks in the first half, the Business Times said on Monday.
The rest of the world in total bought $7.57 billion during the same period, the newspaper quoted Angela Cozzini, global stategist at London-based Cross Border Capital, as saying.
Cozzini's figures were culled from offficial sources including the U.S. Treasury, Securities Industry Association and Federal Reserve Board, the Business Times said.
In the first quarter of the year, Singapore-based investors poured pumped in $717 million. And in the second quarter, their purchases soared to $2.28 billion.
In the whole of 1995, they poured $5.58 billion into U.S. stocks.
The largest Singapore investor is widely thought to be the Government of Singapore Investment Corporation, the Business Times said.
